title: CommInsure whistleblower: Life lesson in ASIC v Westpac
text:
“Insurance is sold, not bought,” Dr Koh told The Australian Financial Review.

The whistleblower - who accused the bank of attempting to bully him into modifying medical opinions and was ultimately sacked - said the case poses problems for the direct life insurance model, where insurance products are sold to consumers without a registered financial adviser making the recommendation via personal, licensed advice.

'The very nature of a hard sell'

ASIC has indicated it wants the federal government to ban the practice of direct life insurance via telesales agents, but Dr Koh said even if phone-based sales were eliminated the common practice of bank branch sales would be affected.

“Chief Justice Allsop held [in the Federal Court judgment] that techniques used by staff in an attempt to personalise their interaction with customers may encourage the belief in their customers that they were being listened to. And when the staff subsequently presented to their customers with a view, it becomes personal or non-general advice," Dr Koh said.

"When we apply that reasoning in the life insurance sales context at a bank branch, the very nature of a hard sell of life insurance via a personalised organic conversation would make such conversations in a professional setting personal advice."

Dr Koh said in his experience working for a major life insurer, bank branch sales were considered a key plank of the distribution strategy.

Although CBA has flagged its intention to sell CommInsure to Pan-Asian insurer AIA, Dr Koh said he expected branches to continue offering insurance products as part of their service offering in order to receive commissions or incentives, although they would be recommending the products of third parties and not in-house insurers.

Advertisement

Bank branch staff who are not listed on ASIC's register of financial advisers are not able to legally provide personal advice on life insurance or any other financial products.

'Well beyond super'

Herbert Smith Freehills partner Michael Vrisakis agreed with Dr Koh's assessment of the Federal Court judgment.

“The commercial significance of this goes well beyond retail superannuation into retail financial products more generally," he said.

“Personal advice can materialise wherever there is an existing relationship with a customer or where engagement with a customer is sufficient to create a belief on the part of the customer that you are acting in their best interests.”

The Financial Services Council, which represents both life insurers and retail superannuation funds, said it was taking the time to review the judgment and consider the implications for members.

CBA has been approached for comment.
description: Life insurance sales could be devastated by the Federal Court’s decision in the corporate regulator’s superannuation dispute with Westpac, says CommInsure’s former chief medical officer.
